2728.22.text: I can look at my business and I know that my business is a success

2731.82.text: because my business has this purpose and my business has this.

2735.64.text: You know this thing that it's doing like this is real,

2739.41.text: and we are making a real difference in people's lives.

2742.69.text: And, having this brought me through that time.

2747.00.text: It also brought our company through that time like,

2749.35.text: this was what our team rallied around.

2752.85.text: And it wasn't easy and as I said like,

2754.73.text: we had to make some hard decisions to set our business up for

2758.18.text: success and set our brand up for the future and you know,

2761.89.text: we decided to really focus on the things that

2765.34.text: we did better than anyone else in the world,

2768.28.text: that was thinking about building community and taking like engaging

2775.64.text: with that community and creating products and creating innovative social

2779.22.text: experiences that they would love and that they would respond to.

2785.89.text: and having like this purpose to kind of

2788.74.text: drive that focus enabled us to you know,

2792.11.text: kind of look for and start thinking about the future and

2796.34.text: as we started thinking about the future of ModCloth like,

2798.74.text: in the last like 12 months or so.

2801.78.text: You know, we knew that involved taking the brand to the next level,

2806.88.text: part of that is, thinking about what a physical presence

2810.51.text: means for ModCloth and what that would like.

2813.62.text: And you know whether that's pop ups or fit shops

2817.51.text: or guide shops or some combination of them,

2823.65.text: we knew that was where we wanted to go.

2825.33.text: We also knew that we needed to work on our own proprietary products,

2830.27.text: so thinking about designing things that you could not

2832.38.text: find anywhere because we know our customer best and we

2835.25.text: know what would fit her and we have all this like,

2836.93.text: great data on what works for her.

2839.94.text: So, in order to do that we actually decided to hire and a new CEO,

2844.22.text: someone who had retail experience and who

2847.50.text: had kind of done all of those things,

2854.48.text: And our new CEO started in January, his name is Matt.

2860.45.text: And you know, since January we have actually

2863.54.text: already launched our first fit shop,

2868.84.text: We did this in LA about a month ago.

2872.96.text: we had customers, community members linking up around the block,

2877.11.text: hundreds of them, some of them waiting for hours to actually get in

2881.41.text: and be able to try in our products and interact with each other,

2884.21.text: interact with the brands and you know, all of this is possible,

2894.21.text: thinking about the future of ModCloth because of

2897.31.text: that core and that purpose and I think like,

2900.58.text: it's part of why I am so passionate about sharing

2904.30.text: this message with other entrepreneurs is because

2906.33.text: I feel like it's easy to think about like,

2912.58.text: there is just this kind of list of things

2914.18.text: that I need to do as an entrepreneur,

2915.33.text: and I need you to check them off and I need to grow a business,

2917.54.text: and I needed to do this and need to do that.

2919.42.text: And, I am not sure that like this concept

2923.05.text: is on that like, well-known list.

2925.79.text: This concept is like find your purpose and find what you're doing.

2931.29.text: And I'd like it to be that.

2932.59.text: I also don't think that the check-off the list is like

2936.21.text: actually you're saying that people should be doing.

2938.01.text: Guess I like - I feel like all entrepreneurs have different

2941.12.text: stories and like come from different backgrounds

2943.20.text: and kind of approach in different ways.

2945.87.text: But I do think this is one thing that like every business or

2950.17.text: it's really nowhere it's going in order to weather rough times

2955.98.text: and to be headed in the right direction in good times.

2959.92.text: Like this is probably like the most important

2962.95.text: thing that I would leave you guys with.

2965.47.text: And I would love to answer some questions.

2970.01.text: Thank you for having me here today.

2981.25.text: So you mentioned that it's okay to look back and cringe.

2985.30.text: But is it possible that your earlier choices even when

2988.27.text: you look back you feel that it is unsophisticated,

2990.72.text: it actually fits the young people of that same age group they

2994.09.text: actually prefer the unsophisticated versions of styles.

2998.04.text: So the question was it's okay to look back

3003.07.text: and cringe but sometimes you find that...

3005.52.text: Yeah maybe the naive version actually fits.

3009.83.text: Yeah, that the naive version is better for a certain

3013.50.text: age group or like for a certain customer.

3015.80.text: So I think I see what you mean and I do think there is definitely

3020.69.text: some validity to - like I don't think it's about necessarily

3026.49.text: like looking back and saying like that wasn't cutting edge

3030.58.text: or that doesn't feel cutting edge because everything will

3034.16.text: feel stale kind of a few years into the future.

3038.34.text: So I do think there is definitely validity to kind of -

3042.59.text: like I feel like maybe what you are asking about is like

3045.77.text: a purposeful throwback or something that feels more,

3049.58.text: I don't know, kind of retro.

3052.55.text: And I think that's totally valid.

3056.20.text: I do think though that if you - so if you feel good about what you're

3064.42.text: putting out into the world like part of the thing that I want

3070.39.text: to convey is like if you feel good about it like get it out there

3075.31.text: and don't just kind of sit on it and hold it in because you want

3079.28.text: to make it perfect because it will never be perfect.

3082.25.text: But, yeah, I do think that there is validity

3085.68.text: to looking back and saying like,

3087.05.text: well, look, this is actually great and it's

3088.93.text: like perfect again in this moment in time.

3096.63.text: Can you talk a little bit about the transition that your company

3100.50.text: made between filling a simple need as a small company selling

3105.96.text: to consumers and you know that they want a product and then

3106.46.text: being able to actually empower those consumers,

3110.90.text: like fulfil yourself and like being able to empower

3112.30.text: your consumers and what contributes to that cycle.

3119.63.text: So the question is about how - what was the transition for ModCloth

3126.76.text: from going from like a purely transactional relationship with our

3129.67.text: community to actually empowering them to be part of the process.

3135.49.text: Yeah, I think - I mean I do think a lot of that

3140.24.text: for ModCloth story was timing for us.

3144.06.text: Like I said, we were kind of - I was like thinking about taking the business

3151.70.text: to the next level at this time where Facebook was really gaining traction

3157.02.text: and like all this stuff on the social web was happening.

3160.43.text: So for me, it like intuitively made sense that whatever business

3165.07.text: I was starting like this had to be a part of it like I look at

3168.40.text: the way I was using Facebook and the way my friends were interacting

3172.33.text: on Facebook and it made sense to me that like because my customers

3176.96.text: were probably pretty similar to me and my friends that they would

3179.18.text: want to interact in that way as well and not just with the brand

3183.12.text: but with kind of each other on the website.

3186.11.text: And giving them that opportunity was going to be something

3190.56.text: that would be not just useful for us because we learn more

3194.48.text: about them that it would actually be a brand differentiator.

3198.22.text: And I think the transition really was around the

3203.13.text: time that we launched our Be the Buyer program

3208.63.text: like having that kind of brainstorm of like,

3212.98.text: yeah, we could - let's ask our customers and let's get them involved,

3218.39.text: It really was just like confluence of what we were thinking about,

3225.44.text: what we were excited about and what was happening in the market like -

3230.27.text: and in the broader like social world that allow that to happen.

3234.74.text: Was that too vague or does that answer your question?

3240.09.text: I like to know you currently have your own designers and

3244.46.text: also I would like to know are you buying and selling globally

3247.94.text: and what's been your experience with that?

3251.09.text: So the question was if we have our own designers which we do,

3254.86.text: so it's definitely something that we see as a big part of ModCloth's

3260.66.text: future and moving forward is doing more and more proprietary design.

3266.20.text: We release about 150 designs a quarter right now,

3271.10.text: they are coming from our own internal design

3272.85.text: team and we see that scaling quickly.

3277.19.text: The other part of the question was whether we work with international

3281.47.text: designers globally and kind of what that...

3286.25.text: So we do sell around the world.

3288.14.text: Our audience is mostly here in the U.S.

3291.36.text: but we do have like a fairly substantial following in Canada

3294.13.text: and Australia and like some of the other English speaking countries

3297.17.text: you'd expect and like high English speaking countries.

3300.29.text: We do work with designers based around the world and

3304.65.text: it can be - it's incredible from a branding perspective

3308.45.text: being able to introduce a designer to the U.S.

3310.60.text: for the first time and bring them into a new market,

3313.21.text: it's great for their business too and for us like

3316.40.text: it's part of how we become known as a place to - you

3319.39.text: can find stuff that you can't get anywhere else.

3322.04.text: But from a purely like retail business perspective,

3326.15.text: it can definitely be a challenge.

3327.80.text: It's hard for designers that haven't

3331.10.text: worked with companies in the U.S.

3333.00.text: before just like all the actual logistics of like bringing

3336.73.text: product in and making sure it's like going to get through

3339.94.text: customs and going to be able to sell in the U.S.

3342.22.text: It can be - because we work with, we really value independent designs,

3348.92.text: we work with a lot of independent designers and some of

3350.84.text: them are really great at design and not so good at logistics

3355.02.text: and some of the other parts of their business.

3356.37.text: So we have to kind of step in and fill that role.

3368.16.text: it's really a cutthroat and it's really a competitive

3371.33.text: space and I know a lot of brands they go over now,

3374.15.text: you see the craziest campaigns but I am just curious what was the

3378.11.text: one thing ModCloth did differently that got its early adopters?

3383.01.text: So the question was what did ModCloth

3385.46.text: do differently to get early adopters.

3388.46.text: And I think - when I think back to the real early adopters

3392.41.text: like people that were joining the brand in 2006 and 2007,

3396.13.text: what we did differently was really go where our customers were at

3399.36.text: a time when other fashion brands weren't thinking about those spaces.

3404.37.text: So being like one of the first brands to really build the fan

3408.96.text: page on Facebook for this audience going to up and coming like

3415.57.text: celebrity gossip bloggers and personal style bloggers because

3418.64.text: we knew - we even like we used to do a lot of advertising,

3422.20.text: we still do, but like we do a lot of

3425.81.text: So like blogs that post pictures of like bunnies and kitties

3428.68.text: and that sort of thing which isn't fashion related,

3431.31.text: so it wasn't like entirely clear to the broader industry

3433.95.text: that they should go and find customers there.

3436.67.text: But we - like I knew because that's the stuff that I

3441.35.text: was interested in and it was new and it was up and

3443.40.text: coming and like my friends were interested in it.

3446.09.text: So we were able to go and like find our customer where she was at and

3450.13.text: I think that was definitely what really spoke to our early adopters.

3455.96.text: They looked at us and saw us as,

3458.22.text: in some ways, like we are early adopters as well like we

3461.40.text: were the first to work with - have partnerships with certain

3466.35.text: fashion bloggers and like be working with them to create

3469.92.text: great content that didn't feel like an ad but talked about

3473.70.text: the brand and like got brand awareness out there.

3477.60.text: Susan, thank you so much it's been fantastic.
